import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
source.919a95b6:
longest_bestselling_titles = booklist[['title', 'list_name', 'weeks_on_list']]\
                             .groupby('title')\
                             .max()\
                             .sort_values('weeks_on_list', ascending = False)\
                             .head(5)
longest_bestselling_titles.rename(columns={'weeks_on_list': 'Weeks on Bestseller List', 'list_name':'List Name'}, inplace=True)
longest_bestselling_titles.index.name = 'Title'
longest_bestselling_titles
source.f5e90364:
what_to_expect = booklist[booklist.title == "WHAT TO EXPECT WHEN YOU'RE EXPECTING"]
what_to_expect_by_year = what_to_expect[['list_year', 'ranking']].groupby('list_year').mean().round(2)
what_to_expect_by_year.rename(columns={'ranking': 'Ranking'}, inplace=True)
what_to_expect_by_year.index.name = 'List Year'
what_to_expect_by_year
source.81d626a2:
what_to_expect_by_year.plot(figsize=(10,8))
plt.xlabel('List Year')
plt.ylabel('Ranking')
plt.title("Ranking of What to Expect When You're Expecting");
source.351cacfc:
title_ranked_number_one = booklist[booklist.ranking == 1]
longest_number_one_titles = title_ranked_number_one[['title', 'list_date']].groupby('title').count().sort_values('list_date', ascending = False).head(5)
longest_number_one_titles.rename(columns={'list_date':'List Date'}, inplace=True)
longest_number_one_titles.index.name = 'Title'
longest_number_one_titles
source.ec621d5e:
longest_number_one_titles.plot(kind='barh', figsize=(10,6))
plt.xlabel('Weeks at #1')
plt.ylabel('Title')
plt.title('Titles Most Often Ranked #1');
source.a9e4f424:
longest_number_one_authors = title_ranked_number_one[['author', 'list_date']].groupby('author').count().sort_values('list_date', ascending = False).head(5)
longest_number_one_authors.rename(columns={'list_date': 'List Date'}, inplace=True)
longest_number_one_authors.index.name = 'Author'
longest_number_one_authors

longest_number_one_authors.plot(kind='barh', figsize=(10,6))

plt.ylabel('Author')
plt.title('Authors Most Often Ranked #1');

source.dac00fb1:
price_list = booklist[booklist.price > 0] 
price_list = price_list[price_list.list_year == 2010]
price_list.plot(kind='scatter', x ='price', y='weeks_on_list', figsize=(20,10), s=20)
plt.xlabel('Price')
plt.ylabel('Weeks on the List')
plt.title('Performance vs Price [for 2010]');

source.7fa6735f:
# Top 100 Bestsellers of the Decade

For further analysis, let's create a data fram with the top 100 bestsellers of the decade (based on number of weeks on the bestseller list) with title, author, list_name, average ranking, and max weeks on the list. This will take a little bit to put together.\
First, we'll concatenate the list_name and title to preserve both columns in the summarized data:
source.3a2d8b5b: Last step, we'll add a list_year column for further analysis and plotting.
source.f5adc8e9: Here's the table we're left with. Looking good!
source.d2223bb8:
# Analysis
Now it's time for some analysis!

Let's start with some information we can pull from the data in it's current form:
source.d8f998a4: It's not surprising that we've seen some of these titles before in the top bestselling lists we've already looked at. Let's see how average ranking and weeks on the list are correlated with a scatterplot.
source.c0c6b4da:
# Recap of Analysis

Here's what we learned from evaluating the bestseller list:
* What to Expect When You're Expecting was the topselling book of the decade, based on weeks on the bestseller list
* Wonder was ranked #1 the longest
* Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard had books ranked #1 the most during the decade
* Of the Top 100 Bestsellers of the Decade (based on weeks on the list):
  * Paperback Nonfiction was the most frequent category, followed closly by Series Books
  * Diary of a Wimpy Kid and Harry Potter were the bestselling Series Books of the decade
  * Dog Man and The Hunger Games were ranked #1 the longest
* Based on the Top 100 list
  * Weeks on the list plotted against average ranking results roughly in a bell curve, meaning books ranked #1 most often don't have an advantage when it comes to longevity on the list
  * The most common average ranking of the bestsellers was approximately 3.5
* Based on price data from 2010
  * Weeks on the list plotted against price results roughly in a bell curve around the average price of $17.76 with outliers for the more expensive books (which aren't highly ranked)
  * The most expensive books on the booklist are Hardcover Graphic Books, such as Absolute All-Star Superman, which is the most expensive book in 2010.
source.8838ecb2: Finally, we'll check for nulls in the data.
source.2e51c6d0: It looks like the movie did help with the popularity of the book, the average ranking increased in 2012, but it was already on the list at the beginning of the dataset. It continued on the bestseller list through 2017.
source.bf7fbc0e:
![superman](https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/41qAtLtJPWL._SX331_BO1,204,203,200_.jpg)

Superman was the most expensive book in 2010! Interestingly, all of the titles priced equal to or over $100 in the entire dataset are hardcover comic books, either DC, Marvel, or Calvin & Hobbes. The Superman title is a 320 page hardcover Superman book that includes 12 issues.
source.d88c73fa: All of the nulls are in descriptive fields that won't impact the analysis much. We'll replace the nulls with a string.
source.a075547d: Now we'll start evaluating the data. Below are the first 5 rows of the dataset.
source.406c2cd8:
# NY Times Bestseller List Analysis

![image](data:image/png;base64,)

An analysis of 10 years of NY Times bestseller list data. The data includes the top 5 bestselling titles across all included categories each week from January 2010 to December 2019. Also included is additional book information and the cumulative number of weeks the book has been on the list. See below for the data dictionary. The analysis will include the following steps:
* Evaluate and clean data
* Analysis
source.5ad3a53b: As suspected, the average ranking of our longest top selling titles follow a pretty clear bell curve, with the most often occuring average ranking right at 3 - 3.5. The lowest average ranking (here, the best, meaning closest to #1) is actually the lowest bin on the plot, although 4 to 5 is not much higher.
source.fb37dcfd: To begin, the libraries will be imported and the data loaded
source.0815576c: Now we'll merge the two tables together:
source.82951edd: Finally, we'll take the top 100 records based on a weeks_on_list sort and check our resulting table.
source.c4cd5e00:
Average title ranking follows sort of a bell curve distribution (more on that below), and the titles spending the longest on the bestselling list are sort of average ranked, especially the outliers with the longest number of weeks on the list. This suggests that some of the titles that rank #1 on the list are more of one hit wonders (or several weeks wonders) while the lower ranked titles have longevity. 

Let's look at the distribution of average ranking in our top 100 bestseller data frame.
source.2e04dda8: Let's also look at the correlation between price and weeks on the list. Because price information is only included through part of 2013, I've picked 2010 for the analysis. I also filtered out any $0 prices in the data.
source.9a8c23f8:
**Data Dictionary** 

| Field | Description |
| :-- | :-- |
| **published_date** | Date the list was published
| **list_name** | Book category
| **list_name_encoded** | Encoded category
| **rank** | Rank on the list for that week
| **isbn13** | ISBN 13 of the book
| **isbn10** | ISBN 10 of the book
| **title** | Title of the book
| **author** | Author of the book
| **description** | Description of the book
| **amazon_product_url** | Amazon URL
| **price** | Price of the book
| **weeks_on_list** | Number of weeks the book was on Best Sellers list

## Top 100 Bestsellers Analysis
First, let's look at how the different booklists perform.

source.948cf146:
## The 5 Top #1 Bestsellers
Based on a count of how many number one rankings by title
source.1523041e: Right away, it looks like we can clean up the columns. Published_date will be renamed to list_date, to clarify that it refers to the published date of the bestseller list. Rank will be changed to ranking, as there's a pandas rank function we don't want to interfere with. ISBN10 is an outdated numbering system (it was superceded by ISBN13), so that column can be removed.
source.cf42548c: The top five bestselling series titles all spent over 250 weeks on the bestseller list, with the top two over 550 weeks! Now let's look at all the titles in the 100 bestsellers list and see how often they ranked #1.
source.2f0fea20: It looks like the higher priced books aren't particularly well performing, and there's a sort of bell curver centered around the average price. The top performing books look to be right in the middle of the average price. Below are the statistics on the price field. The average is 17.76, which fits with the scatterplot above. The maximum priced book in 2010 is 99.99, let's take a look at what that is. We'll also look at the most expensive books of the decade.
source.100b63f0: Then we'll find the average ranking and max weeks_on_list by title and list_name:

source.8c329283: Based on the top 100 bestseller data fram, Paperback Nonfiction and Series Books are the most represented on the list with Trade Fiction Paperback and Picture books following up. These are bigger categories, and appear most often in the original data set, so this makes sense. Let's look closer at the performance of titles on the Series Books list.
